tool.name: Moderate

param.name: layer
param.dialogReference: Point, line, or polygon feature layer to be moderated.
param.pythonReference: Point, line, or polygon feature layer to be moderated.

param.name: add_update
param.displayname: Add new or update existing configuration
param.dialogReference: Choose to add a new moderation configuration to this layer, or to edit an existing configuration.
param.pythonReference: Choose to add a new moderation configuration to this layer, or to edit an existing configuration.

param.name: delete
param.displayname: Delete existing configuration for this layer
param.dialogReference: When checked, the selected moderation configuration will be deleted for the currently selected layer.
param.pythonReference: When checked, the selected moderation configuration will be deleted for the currently selected layer.

param.name: modlist
param.dialogReference: Choose the moderation list to use for this layer. Moderation lists can be shared accross many layers, and each layer can have multiple lists configured but they must configured individually. These moderation lists must be specified in the General Moderation Settings section of the tool.
param.pythonReference: Choose the moderation list to use for this layer. Moderation lists can be shared accross many layers, and each layer can have multiple lists configured but they must configured individually. These moderation lists must be specified in the General Moderation Settings section of the tool.

param.name: mod_fields
param.dialogReference: Select the fields that will be monitored for content that matches the words and phrases from the specified moderation list.
param.pythonReference: Select the fields that will be monitored for content that matches the words and phrases from the specified moderation list.

param.name: sql
param.dialogReference: SQL statement used to select the features that will be moderated. If no SQL statement is provided, all features will be processed every time the script runs.
param.pythonReference: SQL statement used to select the features that will be moderated. If no SQL statement is provided, all features will be processed every time the script runs.

param.name: update_field
param.dialogReference: Field that will be updated when a feature is found that contains at least one of the words or phrases in the moderation list.
param.pythonReference: Field that will be updated when a feature is found that contains at least one of the words or phrases in the moderation list.

param.name: found_value
param.dialogReference: Value that will be calculated for the specified field when a feature is found that contains at least one of the words or phrases in the moderation list.
param.pythonReference: a feature is found that contains at least one of the words or phrases in the moderation list.

param.name: modlists
param.expression: List Name {Filter Type} {Words and Phrases};List Name {Filter Type} {Words and Phrases}...
param.dialogReference:
For each moderation list, provide the following information:

List Name: Assign a name to the moderation list. This value will appear in the drop-down menu for selecting the moderation list use when scanning each layer.

Filter Type: Choose to scan feature for words and phrases that exactly match the provided list of works and phrases. For example, when the filter type is EXACT, if the list contains the word 'duck' the script will update the specified field when the feature contains the word 'duck', but not when it contains the word 'duckling'. When the filter type is FUZZY, the script will update the feature when either 'duck' or 'duckling' are found.

Words and Phrases: Provide a comma-seperated list of words or phrases to scan for.
param.pythonReference:
For each moderation list, provide the following information:

List Name: Assign a name to the moderation list. This value will appear in the drop-down menu for selecting the moderation list use when scanning each layer.

Filter Type: Choose to scan feature for words and phrases that exactly match the provided list of works and phrases. For example, when the filter type is EXACT, if the list contains the word 'duck' the script will update the specified field when the feature contains the word 'duck', but not when it contains the word 'duckling'. When the filter type is FUZZY, the script will update the feature when either 'duck' or 'duckling' are found.

Words and Phrases: Provide a comma-seperated list of words or phrases to scan for. This list is case-insensitive.

param.name: charsubs
param.dialogReference: Some characters are frequently substituted for others in an attempt to get around moderation filters, such as using @ instead of the letter 'a'. To take these substitutions into consideration, list each letter and the equivalent characters for that letter. This list is case-insensitive. List all substitutions for each letter on a single line, without seperators. For example, for the letter 'a', including '@&' in the substitutions space will test for the letter 'a' in place of any @ or & signs found, in order to match the word against the contents of the words and phrases list. This comparison takes place for both EXACT and FUZZY filter types.
param.pythonReference: Some characters are frequently substituted for others in an attempt to get around moderation filters, such as using @ instead of the letter 'a'. To take these substitutions into consideration, list each letter and the equivalent characters for that letter. This list is case-insensitive. List all substitutions for each letter on a single line, without seperators. For example, for the letter 'a', including '@&' in the substitutions space will test for the letter 'a' in place of any @ or & signs found, in order to match the word against the contents of the words and phrases list. This comparison takes place for both EXACT and FUZZY filter types.

tool.summary: Moderate features by updating the value of a field if a word or phrase is found in another field.
tool.usage: When the calculated value means that a feature no longer meets the requirements of a filter on a map or of a definition query on the the layer, it effectively moderates the layer. This tool can also be used to calculate other attributes, such as priority, based on the contents of other fields, such as a user-provided description of an issue.
